properties.name: Archie McPhee
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob 2428 NW Market Street, Seattle, WA 98107This is where not having a bike or car will hurt you. McPhee is a Seattle must-visit, but it\'s over in Ballard and is not really a reasonable walk. Ballard is like old school Norwegian town. Lots of cool stuff, but off the beaten path. I don\'t know if I\'d suggest going over there if you only have one day, but that\'s a really great area. I lived in Ballard back in the day.

properties.name: Bill Speidel's Underground Tour
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob 610 1st Ave # 200, Seattle, WATouristy, but fun. You get to go underground and see Pioneer Square from below. Can be crowded on holidays.

properties.name: Caffe Ladro
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob 600 Queen Anne Ave N, Seattle, WAAnother Ladro. Best coffee. Just say no to Starbucks!

properties.name: Caffe Ladro
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob 801 Pine St, Seattle, WAEXCELLENT coffee. Voted best coffee in Seattle in the Seattle Weekly in 2007. There are multiple locations. I don\'t know if I\'d make a special trip just to go there, but if in the area, worth a stop.

properties.name: Columbia Center
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob 701 5Th Ave, Seattle, WAThis is the tallest building in Seattle. Unparalleled view. I spoke to a person there who seemed to think they would be closed all Memorial Day weekend. Call to confirm this: (206) 386-5151

properties.name: Dilettante Chocolate
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob 416 Broadway East, seattle, waCrazy good chocolate with fantastic tortes, ice cream drinks, coffee desserts with an insane amount of very high quality chocolate. Worth a visit if you\'re strolling along Broadway up on Capitol Hill.

properties.name: Elliott Bay Book Company
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob 101 S Main St, Seattle, WAA must-see book store. Really great. They also have in-store events with some very prominent authors. Check the schedule for when you\'re there. There is also a cafe in the basement which is quite good. Not anything spectacular, but a good lunch place. Also, this is one of the only free bathrooms in the Pioneer Square area!

properties.name: Fantagraphics Bookstore & Gallery
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob 1201 South Vale Street, seattle, waThe heart of independent comics in North America.

properties.name: Fremont Troll
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob N. 36th Street & troll ave. n., seattle, waSome more whimsical Fremont art.

properties.name: Grand Central Bakery at Pioneer Square
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob 214 First Avenue South, Seattle, WA, 98104Fantastic and reasonably priced soups and sandwiches. Really good baked goods too. Also pleasant place to eat and convenient. Right in Pioneer Square. Lot of transients frequent this area. Be aware. My ex-wife got choked by a mentally ill woman down near this area and another man was stabbed in broad daylight coming from a Mariners game. Again, just be cautious.

properties.name: Kerry Park
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob  211 W Highland Dr., Seattle, WA Easily one of the best views of Seattle. And it\'s free, of course. Getting up there is a bit of a climb. Queen Anne is very steep. But worth the effort, I think. There are some nice shops, restaurants, bars, and such on top of Queen Anne, so you can continue up or just head back down to Lower Queen Anne. There are, in my opinion, many more interesting restaurants and coffee shops down in Lower Queen Anne than up.

properties.name: Lenin Statue
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob  600 N 36th, Seattle, WA This is the heart of Fremont. You should just go here and explore the area for several blocks in all directions. You will NOT be disappointed.

properties.name: Macrina Bakery
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob 2408 1st Ave, seattle, waThe baked goods here are superb. They also have lunches. The lunches are a little pricey and last time I was there, I didn\'t feel I got as much as I would have hoped for, but it\'s worth checking out to see what they have. This is a good place to stop in to when you are walking from your hotel over to Lower Queen Anne.

properties.name: Northwest Outdoor Center (NWOC)
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob 2100 Westlake Ave N, seattle, waThis is a lot of fun. 2/hour might seem steep, but it\'s well worth the price. Two hours should be more than enough. Of course, if you\'ve never kayaked before, you should not go out alone. Can be a little choppy because of the wind. Doubles are only a little more per hour. Bring a friend.

properties.name: Pacific Place
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob 600 Pine St Ste 228, Seattle, WAThis and Westlake Center to the south are pretty much the heart of the downtown mall-like shopping experience. Really nothing very unique here. Just every high end shopping type chain and store you can imagine. I wouldn\'t make a trip there expecting to see anything unique, but if you want or need to shop for mall type stuff, this would be the place to go. Bunch of stores to the north of that and just generally around that area.

properties.name: Pike Place Market
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob 1529 Pike Pl, Seattle, WAYep. They throw fish here. Good places to eat. Not great, but fast. Other stores and such down below. Golden Age Collectables, a nice little comics store is down below in the shops. Other marginally interesting little shops.

properties.name: Safeco Field
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob 1250 1st Ave. S., Seattle, WA, United StatesWhere the Mariners play. Considered by many to be one of the best baseball fields in the world, if baseball is your thing.

properties.name: Scarecrow Video
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob 5030 Roosevelt Way Ne, Seattle, WAArguably, the best video store in the country. Certainly the largest on the west coast. May not be worth a trip, but if you get over to the U district, probably worth a stop.

properties.name: Seattle Asian Art Museum
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob 1400 E. Prospect St., Seattle, WA, United StatesI don\'t know that I\'d make the trip just for this, but the Art Museum, water tower, conservatory make Volunteer Park a high priority destination, in my view.

properties.name: Seattle-to-Bainbridge ferry
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob  801 Alaskan Way, seattle, waLeaves from Pier 52 and takes about 35 minutes each way. There\'s really nothing worth seeing in Bainbridge. The only reason you\'d take this trip is to get a whale\'s eye view of Elliott Bay, surrounding islands, and Seattle. I think it\'s like each way. Should be no wait at all if you are on foot. Probably should avoid it during commuting hours. A nice way to hit this might be to get a coffee and sandwich from Grand Central and then just eat on the ferry. Maybe bring a book from Elliott Bay Books or the Seattle Weekly or Stranger to plan out some things to see and do.

properties.name: Smith Tower
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob 506 2nd Ave, Seattle, WAThis is rarely visited by tourists or even most locals. An excellent view, but it\'s in a sketchy part of town. Best to not be around there at dark.

properties.name: Space Needle
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob 47.6205/-122.349Probably really crowded. A little pricey. But a definite must-see. Try to pick a time and day that is slow. Sunset is always the most crowded. You can get there from your hotel by walking or taking the monorail. Maybe best way is to take the monorail there and walk back. The Seattle Center also has many events. That\'s where Folklife will be over the Memorial Day weekend. The Key Arena is also there where the Sonics play (at least until the franchise is moved to Oklahoma).

properties.name: Uwajimaya
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob 600 5th Avenue South, Seattle, WAThis is a very large Asian grocery store. There is an EXCELLENT book store in here also called Kinokuniya which has a massive selection of manga. A large supply of Osamu Tezuka. There is a small food court here with a lot of delicious stuff. This also sits right in the middle of the International District or "ID."

properties.name: Volunteer Park
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob Very nice park with a modest, but beautiful conservatory. There is also a water tower here which can be climbed and offers a lovely view of Seattle. The Asian Art Museum is also here and occasionally has events worth catching.

properties.name: Waterfall Garden Park
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob 219 2nd Ave S, seattle, waFree to enter. No admission. A great place to eat or drink coffee. Popular with area workers for lunch. Best to avoid lunch time there. I worked down in Pioneer Square and this like the Smith Tower is a hidden, but very worthwhile stop.

properties.name: Westin Seattle
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob 1900 5th Ave, Seattle, WA

properties.name: Zeitgeist Art And Coffee
properties.description: Posted by Atomicbob A fantastic place to chill out. Sort of out of the way. Really top notch and cool.
